questions.question_text: Which VLAN bridge priority value is assigned by the set spantree root command?

discussion.content:
Based on this site: https://quizlet.com/252936843/ccna-practice-1-jia-flash-cards/
the answer is 32768

comments.content: Yes you are right thanks icdaniel

That Flash Card is wrong bro. Usiing the spanning-tree vlan 10 root primary, STP set the priority to 8192.
https://learningnetwork.cisco.com/thread/35121
So teh correct answer is A= 8192

choices.A: It defines a wildcard mask to identify the size of the network.
choices.C: It defines the network by its classful entry.
choices.D: It defines which networks are used for virtual links.

questions.question_text: Which purpose of the network command in OSPF configuration mode is true?

discussion.content:
The answer is A. Area is defined in the Area "Range" command. 
https://www.cellstream.com/reference-reading/tipsandtricks/369-what-is-the-network-command-in-ospf-and-bgp
I believe the network command only identifies the interface not the size of the network. I.e. "Network 10.1.1.1 0.0.0.0" identifies the exact ip address of the interface. So answer is B.

B. defines the area ID

as you can also type
network 10.0.0.1 0.0.0.0 area 0

which the wildcard mask does not identify the size of the network

questions.question_text: Which configuration enables OSPF for network 192.168.1.0/24?

discussion.content: You can still use subnet mask as the router will convert it to wildcard for you, but it is not recommended

this the correct way

Router ospf 1
network 192.168.1.0 0.0.0.255 area 0
shouldn't this answer have wildcard mask instead of subnet mask?

choices.C: Verify that auto summary is enabled.
choices.D: Verify that the interface is up.
choices.B: Verify that the network command has been configured.
choices.F: Verify that the router ID has been configured.
choices.E: Verify that an IPv4 address has been configured.

questions.question_text: Which three checks must you perform when troubleshooting EIGRPv6 adjacencies? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
Don't get confused with EIGRP IPv4
EIGRP for IPv6 doesn't include network cmd

PortFast works on Access Ports where you connect end devices. However, enabling it on trunk ports could cause temporary loops on Layer 2, but that's not to say that you shouldn't do it, but that is a limitation of PortFast if/when enabled on trunk ports, and it may be worth avoiding if this causes issues on the network.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/lan/catalyst4000/8-2glx/configuration/guide/stp_enha.html#wp1033890
